channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Russia Declares New Phase of War as Forces Clash in East
item.description: Ukraine said it was resisting Russia’s initial thrusts in a sprawling offensive that could reshape the conflict. The Pentagon estimated that Moscow has added thousands of troops in Ukraine in recent days.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A strike in a residential neighborhood of Kharkiv on Tuesday killed at least three people.

item.title: South Africa Live Updates: President Declares a State of Disaster After Flooding
item.description: Nearly 4,000 homes have been destroyed and more than twice as many damaged in the Durban area after a week of punishing rains and mudslides. The death toll is now 443, with roughly four dozen people unaccounted for.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Standing near a bridge north of Durban, South Africa, that was destroyed in recent flooding.

item.title: Russia’s Thrust in Eastern Ukraine Combines Firepower and New Caution
item.description: The military campaign that Moscow said it had now begun appears much more methodical than those it pursued in the war’s first days
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: An artillery strike on Monday killed at least one person and wounded another in a residential area in Kharkiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Myanmar’s Health System Is in Collapse, ‘Obliterated’ by the Regime
item.description: The country is also now one of the most dangerous places in the world to be a medical worker. At least 30 doctors have been killed since the coup, a rights group says.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Patients with gunshot wounds in an emergency ward last March in Yangon, Myanmar. The staff had shut down the hospital as part of mass protests against the military coup weeks earlier, but were secretly treating injured protestors.

item.title: How Memes Are Driving Ukraine’s Fundraising Efforts
item.description: A campaign using internet memes and merchandise has rallied international public support for Ukraine in its war with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: T-shirts and stickers featuring the Virgin Mary holding an antitank missile are being sold to help fund Ukrainian aid organizations.

item.title: Afghanistan School Explosions: At Least 6 Dead in Kabul
item.description: More than a dozen people were also wounded, one as young as 7. The attacks again challenged the Taliban’s promise of security, and stoked deep-seated fears in the Shiite community.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Yaqoob Akbary
item.media:description: Taliban fighters stand guard at the site of an explosion in front of a school in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Tuesday.

item.title: Drawn and Caricatured: French Cartoonists on the Campaign Trail
item.description: Cartoonists play a high-profile role in France’s political discourse, and they have been busy drawing the presidential candidates as the race approaches its end.
item.dc:creator: Saskia Solomon

item.title: New Rocket Fire From Gaza Follows Rising Tensions in Israel
item.description: The first strike from Gaza in several months came just days after clashes in and around the Aqsa Mosque compound, a sacred site for both Muslims and Jews.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israel’s Iron Dome anti-missile system launching to intercept rockets fired from the Gaza Strip during the war last year.

item.title: Ukraine War Divides Orthodox Faithful
item.description: Around the world, national churches, parishes and even families are reassessing relations with Patriarch Kirill of Moscow, who has encouraged Russia’s aggression.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Sophia Kishkovsky
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A worshiper lighting a candle on Sunday at the Church of the Elevation of the Cross in Udine, Italy. The church has severed all ties with the Moscow Patriarchate over its support for the war in Ukraine.

item.title: To Push Back Russians, Ukrainians Hit a Village With Cluster Munitions
item.description: The New York Times verified that Ukraine’s forces appeared to fire at least two of these internationally banned weapons in a neighborhood, putting Ukrainian civilians at extreme risk.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and John Ismay
item.media:description: The remains of a destroyed Russian armored vehicle in a neighborhood damaged during the war in Husarivka, Ukraine.

item.title: French Candidates’ Economic Programs Hold Key to the Election
item.description: Promising tax cuts, higher wages and changes in the retirement age, President Macron and Marine Le Pen vie for undecided voters.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron on the campaign trail last week in Le Havre, France.

item.title: A Door-to-Door Effort to Find Out Who Died Helps Low-Income Countries Aid the Living
item.description: Many developing countries don’t keep official death records. A novel effort uses “electronic autopsies” to count deaths, and record their cause.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Finbarr O’Reilly

item.title: China’s Covid Shutdowns Go Far Beyond Shanghai
item.description: Cities and towns across the country are shutting down, hoping to sidestep the pitfalls and stumbles that Shanghai has faced battling the Omicron variant.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Testing for the virus in Shanghai on Tuesday. The city of Wuhu in Anhui Province is entering a similar lockdown after reporting two Covid cases.

item.title: A ‘Wild West’ of Marijuana Shops Grows in Toronto
item.description: Permitted to operate during the pandemic, even during lockdowns, Toronto’s marijuana shops have flourished and changed the character of an iconic neighborhood.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Ian Willms

item.title: Letizia Battaglia, Photographer of Mafia Brutality, Dies at 87
item.description: Her images of victims on the streets of Palermo were stamped on the nation’s consciousness as she challenged the grip mobsters had on her native Sicily.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ms. Battaglia at her home in 2017. “I never thought of myself as an artist,” she said, “and I am still astonished to enter into a museum and see my work.”

item.title: Biden Restores Climate to Environmental Law, Reversing Trump
item.description: A new rule requires agencies to analyze the climate impacts of proposed highways, pipelines and other projects, and gives local communities more input.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Biden administration plans to resurrect requirements of the 50-year-old National Environmental Policy Act that had been removed by President Donald J. Trump.

item.title: World Economic Outlook Dims as War and Pandemic Cast a Pall
item.description: The International Monetary Fund’s new World Economic Outlook expects growth to slow to 3.6 percent this year. The group is one of many to slash their forecasts recently.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian refugees waited to sign up for temporary residence permits in Brussels. The war in Ukraine is among the overlapping crises dimming expectations for the global economy this year.

item.title: ‘Big Screaming Headlines’
item.description: Coronavirus cases have risen in major cities. Hospitalizations have not.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A Covid-19 testing site in Brooklyn yesterday.

item.title: A Mask Mandate Ends Midflight, Sparking Cheers and Alarm
item.description: Airport terminals and flights erupted in applause, while some passengers said the abrupt policy change put them at risk.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Brittany Murray/MediaNews Group/Long Beach Press-Telegram, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Travelers at Los Angeles International Airport on Monday. The T.S.A. announced that it would stop enforcing its mask mandate after a federal judge in Florida struck down the requirement.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A Russian offensive in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Onlookers at the scene of a missile strike that hit a tire fitting plant in Lviv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Which U.S. Airlines Dropped Their Mask Mandate
item.description: After a federal mandate was struck down, the major carriers said masks would be optional on their domestic flights.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:description: Most large U.S. airlines, including American, JetBlue and United, said passengers and crew would no longer be required to wear masks on domestic flights.

item.title: U.N. Official Said He Tested Positive for Covid After In-Person Meeting
item.description: One meeting had included the U.N.’s secretary general, but everyone in the room was wearing masks, a spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Martin Griffiths briefs reporters on the humanitarian situation in Ukraine at United Nations headquarters in New York on Monday. He tested positive for the coronavirus later in the day.

item.title: Ukraine Says Russia Begins Assault in the East After Raining Missiles Nationwide
item.description: The president of Ukraine and a top national security aide said the Russian offensive, anticipated for weeks, had finally begun after a Russian missile barrage that included the first deadly strike on the western city of Lviv.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf, Ivan Nechepurenko and Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters struggle to extinguish a blaze from a missile strike Monday on a tire-fitting plant in Lviv in western Ukraine. At least seven people were killed in missile strikes on the city.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Russia Launches Assault in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: Plus China’s lockdowns slow its economy and France’s candidates vie for undecided voters.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times

item.title: Prisoners Held by Both Russia and Ukraine Appeal to Leaders for Help
item.description: Two British fighters held by Russian asked to be traded for Viktor Medvedchuk, a wealthy Ukrainian ally of Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Oksana Marchenko calling last week for Ukraine to release her husband, Viktor Medvedchuk, a wealthy Ukrainian with close ties to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

item.title: Thousands of Ukrainian Civilians Are Holed Up in a Steel Plant in Mariupol, Officials Say
item.description: Some 2,000 civilians who were driven from their homes have sheltered in a network of tunnels beneath the plant, an aide to the city’s mayor said.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht

item.title: A Second Global Covid-19 Summit Led By the White House Is Set for May
item.description: Efforts to subsidize more global vaccinations have stalled in Congress, and new coronavirus cases are on the rise in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:description: A participant in a Covid-19 vaccine trial in Soweto, South Africa, last year.

item.title: Bleak Assessments of Russian Economy Contradict Putin’s Rosy Claims
item.description: While Vladimir Putin boasts that Russia is holding up under Western sanctions, his central bank chief and the mayor of Moscow warned that the worst was yet to come.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Patricia Cohen
item.media:description: Contrary to President Vladimir V. Putin’s optimism, two senior Russian officials cautioned on Monday that the real economic pain was yet to come.

item.title: Rare Russian Strike Hits Lviv, A City Relatively Untouched By Violence
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of displaced people from other parts of Ukraine have fled to, or through, Lviv to escape the fighting. Then it landed on their doorstep.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rises from the site of a missile strike in Lviv on Monday.

item.title: Russian attack on Lviv shakes sense of security in a relatively safe city.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shoppers at a bazaar in Lviv earlier this month. Strikes on the city on Monday upended a sense of security compared to other areas of Ukraine.

item.title: Calls for Covid funding are renewed as doses near expiration.
item.description: A tense battle may soon resume over the stalled $10 billion pandemic aid package that senators failed to pass earlier this month.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alorovictor Bernard, 24, receiving the Johnson & Johnson vaccine from Eva Nasser, 38, at the Gurey Primary Health Care Center in Juba, South Sudan, in October. South Sudan has administered thousands of shots donated from the United States.

item.title: The ‘Messy Middle’
item.description: The West is arming Ukraine and punishing Russia. Today we look at the countries that aren’t.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Timothy A. Clary/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Volodymyr Zelensky addresses the United Nations Security Council this month.

item.title: A Portrait of South Georgia: Abundance, Exploitation, Recovery
item.description: A series of ecological initiatives, including the eradication of several invasive species, has dramatically revived the life and landscape of this remote sub-Antarctic island.
item.dc:creator: Eric Guth and Jennifer Kingsley

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A showdown in Mariupol.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A rocket barrage slammed into central Kharkiv Sunday afternoon, lighting apartment buildings and a market on fire.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Russia Demands Surrender in Mariupol
item.description: Plus India and the W.H.O. clash over the accounting of Covid’s death toll.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: A rocket barrage slammed into central Kharkiv Sunday afternoon, lighting apartment buildings and a market on fire.

item.title: Death Toll From Pakistani Airstrike Rises to 45, Afghan Officials Say
item.description: The airstrikes in eastern Afghanistan early Saturday morning escalated already simmering tensions between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: Safiullah Padshah, Christina Goldbaum and Ihsanullah Tipu Mehsud
item.media:description: A protest against Pakistani airstrikes in Khost, Afghanistan, on Saturday.

item.title: Americans Over 60 Should Get Second Booster, Official Says
item.description: Citing data from Israel, the Biden administration’s Covid response coordinator said a second booster offered significant protection to older people.
item.dc:creator: William Lamb
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Ashish K. Jha, the nation’s Covid-19 response coordinator, said data showed “substantial reduction” in illness among people over 60 who received a second booster shot.

item.title: Marine Le Pen Proposes Ban on Muslim Women Wearing Head Scarves
item.description: Marine Le Pen, the far-right contender, has proposed a ban on Muslim women wearing head scarves in public.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Marine Le Pen campaigning Friday in Pertuis, France, where she was confronted about her plan to bar head scarves in public.

item.title: Atrocities in Ukraine War Have Deep Roots in Russian Military
item.description: Like the shelling of cities, the seemingly pointless, close-up killing of individuals recalls wars in Chechnya. Do they reflect intent, or only indifference, propaganda and a military culture of violence?
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tetiana Petrovna reacted in horror in a garden where Roman Havryliuk, his brother Serhiy Dukhli and an unidentified victim were found on April 4 in Bucha, Ukraine.

item.title: Pope Speaks of Ukraine’s Suffering on ‘an Easter of War’
item.description: In his blessing to pilgrims, Pope Francis quoted a manifesto against nuclear weapons and said conflict in Europe should bring increased attention to violence around the world.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis greeting the faithful as he rode in his Popemobile through St. Peter's Square on Sunday.

item.title: Days After the Sinking of the Russian Warship, Moskva, Questions Linger
item.description: A talk-show host, who usually reflects the Kremlin’s line, questioned how the ship was lost.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: A satellite image released by Maxar Technologies showed the warship Moskva docked at a port in Sevastopol, Crimea, last week.

item.title: Worshipers Fill Pews in Lviv on Easter Sunday for Services That Remember War
item.description: Commemorations in Ukraine’s small Roman Catholic community combined ancient traditions with the reality of the war.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Communion at St. Anthony Church in Lviv, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Yemen’s Houthis Went From Ragtag Militia to Force Threatening Gulf Powers
item.description: Iran’s cultivation of the Houthis over the years of war in Yemen has armed them with missiles and drones, endangering Washington’s partners and Tehran’s rivals, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Security forces for the Houthi rebels in March in Sana, Yemen.

item.title: Pope Calls for Peace in Ukraine on What He Called ‘Easter of War’
item.description: Instead of learning from the heavy toll taken by the pandemic, and emerging with strengthened solidarity, rivalry had prevailed, the pope said.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis at the Vatican on Sunday.

item.title: A Violent Crisis
item.description: The Brooklyn shooting and other headline-making violence are part of a broader trend.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A police officer watches as people enter the 42nd Street Grand Central subway station in New York, after a mass shooting on a Brooklyn subway last week.

item.title: ‘They Are Gone, Vanished’: Missing Persons Haunt Ukrainian Village
item.description: In a Russian-occupied village, five men went off to feed cattle. Their relatives and neighbors are wondering what happened to them.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks
item.media:description: A cellar in Husarivka, Ukraine. At least three skulls were recovered there earlier this month.

item.title: Rare Overlap of Holy Days Shows Jerusalem’s Promise and Problems
item.description: In its Old City, a Christian, a Jew and a Muslim marked Easter, Passover and Ramadan. To some, it’s a “symphony.” To others, a reminder of division.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of the Old City of Jerusalem on Thursday, the eve of the first convergence of the three holidays since 1991.

item.title: The World’s Broken Promise of Asylum
item.description: Britain’s new plan to send thousands of asylum seekers to Rwanda exposes the fragile nature of the global refugee compact, which has always fallen prey to domestic politics.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Britain’s Border Force taking refugees to Dover, England, last year after picking them up in the English Channel.

item.title: Fighting for Her Life, Far From Ukraine
item.description: A 5-year-old Ukrainian girl with a brain tumor was one of several children brought for treatment in the United States after their country was invaded by Russia.
item.dc:creator: Isadora Kosofsky and Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Isadora Kosofsky for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bogdan Kretsul, 8, and Khrystyna playing at Target House, a residential building where the families of children receiving treatment live.

item.title: Israeli Police Stop Muslim Worshipers From Entering Holy Site
item.description: An Islamist party said it was freezing its involvement in the coalition government after the Israeli police blocked Muslim access to the Aqsa Mosque compound to prevent clashes.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Israeli security forces patrolling on Sunday near the Aqsa Mosque compound, known to Jews as the Temple Mount.

item.title: North Korea Launches 2 Short-Range Missiles
item.description: The missile test, the North’s 12th of the year, took place as South Korea and the United States were preparing to begin joint military exercises.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: News coverage of North Korea’s missile test on a screen in a Seoul train station on Sunday.

item.title: Macron Vows Ambitious Green Policies, Wooing the Left in Runoff
item.description: France’s president is trying to tap into the country’s large pool of left-wing voters, but many are hesitant to back him.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France speaking at a campaign rally in Marseille on Saturday.

item.title: Israel Steps Up Raids in Palestinian Territories in Response to Attacks
item.description: At least 14 Palestinians have been killed in a widespread Israeli military operation in the West Bank, launched in response to a string of attacks in Israel that killed 14 people.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Khuloud Zakarneh, the mother of 16-year-old Mohammad Zakarneh, who she says was shot and killed by Israeli forces, comforts her daughter Sedra in their home in the West Bank city of Jenin.

item.title: Russia Fires Missile Barrage at Ukrainian Cities and Military Targets
item.description: The strikes seemed aimed at hampering Ukraine’s war fighting capacity as the conflict shifts to eastern Donbas region, and at responding to the sinking of a Russian warship.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Marc Santora and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: A shopping center in central Kharkiv was struck by what appeared to be guided missiles on Saturday. Russian forces continue to strike cities across Ukraine.
